reviews.review_msg: I might get flamed for this but I thought the course was decent. My big advice was to read the textbook!!! I barely studied his lecture notes and did well on the exams. I recommend understanding concepts plus memorizing since he asked both types of questions on the tests. Evolution has some very abstract concepts so do not cram last minute.

This is the worst class with the worst prof I have ever taken. Exams, assignments, and tutorials are not coordinated at all. No one is of any help and all they tell you is to read the textbook. I do not understand how he was chosen to be a prof for this class

I don't believe in bad mouthing a professor unless they are horrendous, so I will instead give advice. Read the textbook religiously, page to page. Practice the supplementary "problems" he provides with no end. Force him in class (by asking questions in advance) to keep the class going, as it often repeats. Or do not take this class.

This was probably the worst class I have ever taken. The course material was pretty straightforward, however the exams were totally left field and were more theory based. On top of that, his teaching wasn't the greatest, and tutorials and assignments did not correlate. I totally regret taking the course with him, try to take it with someone else...

Overall he is a "fair" prof, not the best, not the worst. His questions made you apply concepts learned, which are excellent, if only he actually taught the concepts well. Heavy use of textbook readings, and class/tutorials do little to explain the readings in a better manner. Overall, good guy, bad class.

While I think that Alex was actually good at explaining concepts, he was AWFUL at writing questions. No idea what he wanted half the time. And just telling people to read an entire textbook was not helpful at all. TA's also didn't help much. He's a nice guy though and has a good sense of humour.

People really seemed to dislike him, but I've had FAR worse profs in university. He tried to make things interesting. I rather liked his class. His class has more applied questions vs. pure memorization which a lot of people HIGHLY disliked, but it seemed to work for me. Hated that he gave a 2 pg research essay worth 3% like one week before finals.

He is a nice guy, but unfortunately didn't take the time to structure the class. The notes have little to do with the textbook and the textbook has little to do with the class. All his questions were really open ended and marked extremely hard. T.A's could have been replaced with a Santa decoration: useless. Unable to answer basic questions. AVOID!

Nice guy, bad prof. Exams are all application type questions, but his lectures are summaries of the text and mostly conceptual. Isn't clear with what he wants, and not entirely fair with marking. I didn't try as hard in this class as I should have, but he was no help. I'll probably end up retaking with a better prof.

He is bad at explaining and his questions are confusing. He does not communicate with his TAs so they have no idea what is going on. When you ask for clarification of questions they don't even understand the questions he makes up himself. Notes are completely useless, filled with pictures and doesn't cover main concepts from the book.
As Frank Costanza once said, "This guy... this is not my kind of guy."

Alex really knows his stuff and he seems really passionate about the material. Unfortunately, he's not a good prof. The tutorials and lectures did little to prepare me for exams. I felt like I was studying in the dark when it came to exam time. The tutorials were pointless and lectures tended to be rather vague. Try to avoid this prof if possible

Alex is a great guy; He is very approachable, and acts kindly to his students. Sadly, his course is questionable at best. In example, one entire tutorial (50min) was spent explaining Phylogenetic tree formation; we were never examined on this. You'll spend hours reading, and class won't ever help to explain what you read before hand. Do not take.

Quick list of 'problem areas': Under explained concepts. Over explained details. Baren class notes. Misleading exam questions. Little feedback via marking (doesn't explain mark distribution). Poor use of time in tutorials. Last minute or poorly thought out assignments. Exhaustive use of textbook. Intended target audience: PhD students.

There is only one problem with this prof. It is not that his class is extremely watered down. Its not that his exams are very concentrated. Its not that his tutorials are pointless. It's that he's a brand new professor. Sure he should have had a year of PDP, but it seems like his target audience is PhD, not 2nd/3rd year students.

Nice guy & obviously really smart, but he doesn't explain things well & seems to forget we're not all as smart as he is. Needs to be able to simplify his explanations and be a little more clear. Wouldn't recommend taking a class with him right now, but he does have potential to be a great prof. Threw a lot of entertaining material in there for us.

Would not recommend. His lecture notes are very broad, exams are very detailed. He says read the textbook, but most of the textbook is material that is irrelevant to the course material. Tutorials were useless. I had a great TA, but we did nothing except for quizzes and read papers when we could've been going over concepts. No exam review, nothing.
Should have been an online course, all he does is tell you to go read the book. Not that it helps..

When it comes down to it, he can't teach. He doesn't go into ANY kind of detail and just expects us to understand everything hes not saying. The textbook is useless and unrelated. Both the texts and lectures are filled with information we're not tested on and the information we do need is no where to be found. 50% average is his fault, NOT OURS.

He's a pretty bad prof. His lectures are fairly round-about. He tends to skim over topics vaguely, but then expects very specific answers on exams. The average for both midterm exams were right around 50%. Honestly, the best part of this course was filling out the prof evaluation forms.

He is the worst professor I have had yet at SFU. Lectures are not informative and his exams are not fair at all. The only advice he ever gives is read the textbook. I have been reading the textbook and his exam is not relevant. He should reflect on the fact that the class average is so low, and that it is likely not the students' fault but his own.

hate to say this cause he's such a nice guy and really knowledgeable about the course.. but he is awful at teaching. Quiz and exam questions were vague and unclear and he expected very specific and detailed answers. The average for both midterms was around 50, which is extremely low for bisc300.

I'm not here to bad mouth the guy, but he was a pretty awful prof. He does seem like a generally nice guy, but not much of a teacher. Purple-monkey-dishwasher (for any Simpsons fans who need cheering up :)

Need more ability to explain the concepts. USELESS TUTORIALS the only good part was to have weekly quizzes at the beginning of tutorials rest of it was a waste of time. Should have discussed and solved questions relevant to the exams in the tutorial. Also,one of the TAs didn't know the course well.

"A naive professor" can best describe Chubaty. He has little experience with teaching. Class time was spent explaining pictures rather than concepts. Tutorial time was spent vaguely explaining concepts rather than applying them. Midterms were somewhat fair. He gave no indication as to what you got right or wrong on each question (Arbitrary mark)

tough course, unfair midterm questions. TAs always say your answer is not specific enough!! and give zero out of 10 mark!!    his notes are just summaries of the textbook with more pictures than explanations!!

He is a brand new 'sessional' professor and it shows. Class is concept based whereas the exams and assignments were applications of the concepts. There was no previous practice with applying concepts as class ended up being a textbook summary and tutorials ended up being largely useless. AVOID until the class structure improves.

Overall he can clearly talk and you can see he enjoys it. Unfortunately he cannot structure the class. Assignments were paced randomly. Midterms were ridiculous and he uses an excuse to say students dont answer questions to say that an avg was over 50 instead of saying it was way below because it was unfair. Ridiculous 10 markQ on 32 or 36 mark MT

If you are a mind reader, then this class should be easy. Then again, if you're a mind reader, any class should be easy. The prof is extremely vague and the tutorials were just a way to keep students in one place an hour a week. Try to avoid this prof if possible, or be a psychic. Either or

Chubaty has to potential teach. However the way class is structured is very poor. The class is a summary of the textbook. Tutorials do not apply concepts, but rather recite them. You should be dedicated to reading the book and studying attentively, otherwise this class will become overwhelming very quickly.

If you could avoid this prof, do it! He is terrible at explaining. His lectures are useless and very brief. His exams are harshly marked and the questions are extremely ambiguous. You just can't study for them cause he doesn't say what he expects us to know. One exam question was a random graph. His TA's were also useless. Worst course ever!

Takes forever to get to the point and sometimes doesn't even get to the point. His lecture slides are all pictures and he just talks in round about explanations. Midterm was very hard considering the average was ~50% for a bio class. Gave an assignment 5 days before midterm 1, now giving another assignment week of midterm 2.

His lectures are educational and entertaining, but expects students to "read his mind" about what he wants as answers on assignments -- if you want a diagram, SAY SO. The midterm was not representative of the material emphasized in class, tutorials, or even the midterm review.

It's really hard to judge what could be on his exams. Sometimes an obscure experiment from the textbook ends up being a 4 mark question on an exam that's out of 32 marks. Things he emphasized didn't make it onto the midterm yet things we barely covered were on there. Not a bad guy though, and he tries to make lectures interesting
He's pretty cute and he makes class interesting.
